SystemOutput2: The patient is a 26-year-old female who has had low back pain for about 8 years after a fall in an ABC store. She was referred to physical therapy only once or twice, and was treated with electrical stimulation and heat. The pain has been continuous, but has been at varying degrees. She had a son in August 2008, and has had back pain since giving birth. She fell 4 to 5 days ago while mopping the floor and landed on her low back again, right onto her tailbone. She was seen by Dr. X on 01/10/09 and has a followup appointment scheduled for 02/10/09.

The patient complains of a rash on his upper arms and torso. The rash is itchy. The patient denies any shortness of breath, wheezing, swelling, lips, tongue, or throat. The patient denies any nausea or headaches. The patient has not applied anything to the rash.
Otherwise reviewed and noted as noted on 04/15/2005.
Accutane.
No headaches. No visual, hearing, or swallowing difficulties. No changes in bowel or urinary habits.
Born at 32 weeks' gestation, 4 pounds 11 ounces. He was placed in an incubator for 3 weeks. He had jaundice, but was not treated.
Noncontributory.
Back pain after a fall.
Mr. XYZ has a history of IV drug abuse as well as depression. He is currently on methadone maintenance. He has a room-mate.

The patient is a 57-year-old female who works in the hospital. She has bunion deformity of the second toe and MTP joint on her right foot. She also has deformity of the second and third toes of her left foot. She has had bunion deformity since 13 years ago. Since that time, the bunion has slowly been coming back. She has been using orthotics to provide some relief, but she continues to have significant pain.
Born at the Women's Hospital. Spontaneous. 7 pounds 3 ounces. No complications. Cleared for hearing test and screening.
No smoking or alcohol. He works as a data operator for an IT company.
The patient is going home with her son.

The patient moved to the United States from the Philippines in 1984. He has a green card. He lives in an apartment nearby. He is not married. He has no children. He has high school education. He works. He smokes cigarettes. He has no alcohol. He used to use illicit drugs, but not anymore. He has a case manager, Mr. XYZ, who is in counselling with him.

The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male who has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and a stroke in 2002. He also has a past medical history of right-sided weakness and numbness. He came to us in 2001 for weakness and numbness in his legs. It has never gone away. It has moved to his hands and areas above his knees. It is mostly burning and numbness. The main problem with him is that he has pain. It is not that much of a concern. For the last six months, he has been unable to feel anything hot in his hands. Things slip out of his hand. He has no weakness. He has a feeling of clumsiness and a lot of sensation. He has been having jerking in his shoulders and both hands. It has been going on for a long time but now he is noticing it more than before. He has no tremor. He has no neck pain. He is using a walker because he does not feel safe walking. He has tried different medicines. Oxycodone has given him some relief. Gabapentin has not worked at all. He has not had a good night's sleep for many years. He was transferred to a nursing home six months ago after the heart attack and pacemaker. He was transferred to a nursing home. They stopped his insulin and since then he has been taking tablets for that. He has no back pain. No change in bathroom routine. He has no accidents or injuries.
Followup.

The patient has a history of left hip pain and shoulder pain. He also has a history of leg swelling for the last couple of weeks. He denies any new skin lesions in his legs. He denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, hormonal imbalances, vision and hearing problems, chronic depression, headaches, and thyroid dysfunction.
The patient lives with both of his parents. He is in 4th grade and is in regular mainstream classes at school. No special education classes.

The patient complains of lightheadedness and balance problems. He states that he has had this in the past with vertigo. He states that he just feels lightheaded when he changes positions. He states that he usually gets better when he sits down, but it is not completely gone for 15 to 30 minutes. He states that he feels shaky and weak. He has been taking lorazepam, but that has not helped. His blood pressure has been elevated, and they have increased his dose of metoprolol to see if this is causing his symptoms.
amoxicillin.
Anemic, bipolar disorder, anxiety, history of tubal ligation, and frequent flyer.
He is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. He is single. He works as a payroll representative. He used to work in the jewelry business, with chemicals.
Migraine.
Cipro and Flagyl.

The patient is a 51-year-old female with a history of right thumb stenosing tendinosis. The patient was seen in the emergency room with the diagnosis of right trigger finger. The patient states that her right thumb is locking and unable to move. She has been diagnosed with stenosing tendinosis. The patient was given the option of releasing the A1 pulley, which is a common procedure for this type of tendinosis. The patient has agreed to the above plan.

The patient has a food journal with a calorie range of 26 to 30. She is exercising regularly and she is a member of Overeaters Anonymous. Her sponsor has told her to think about snacks that can help with her diabetes. She is feeling a lot better and has lost weight, but she does not have any information on diabetic exchanges.

Eye cataract surgery and left knee replacement.

The patient's son is 58 years old and has a history of glaucoma, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and RA. His eldest brother died at the age of 92 of "old age." His two younger brothers followed in their 70s after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. His mother and father died in their mid 80s of "old age."

The patient is a 41-year-old male who works as a cook in a coffee shop. Hot oil splashed onto his arm. He does not know how the oil splashed, but the burn is on the medial aspect of his arm from the elbow to the wrist. He was brought to the emergency department for treatment.
The patient will be home with his family.

The patient's white blood cell count is back to normal. However, he has been having a lot of pain in his left shoulder and lower back over the past several days. He has been smoking cigarettes to help with the pain. I think the left shoulder pain could be due to impingement syndrome. He has not taken any medication for it yet and he has forgotten to make an appointment with the orthopedist. He has also been eating poorly. I think with the right diet and regimen, he will be on a better track towards attaining a healthy weight and lifestyle. He is having a lot of difficulty weaning off cigs. He has not had any other urinary symptoms. I will order a urine sample for today's visit to see if he has an infection. He also has one leg more swollen than the other.
Continue home exercise as tolerated. Follow up on diet for the next month.

The patient is a 29-year-old white male who comes in today complaining of swelling on his right hand and arm after being stung by a Yellow Jacket Wasp yesterday. He usually sees Dr. XYZ, but he was not available. The patient states he has been stung by a wasp many times in the past. He states he usually swells up, but he has never had any severe reactions. He states he did have a mild reaction to anaphylaxis type reactions yesterday, but he did not have any anaphylaxis type reactions. He has had no shortness of breath, throat closing, anxiety, or fast heart beat after he has been stung.
Dilaudid 4 mg IM.
The patient is a nonsmoker. He occasionally drinks alcohol and marijuana.
The patient is a 10-year-old smoker. He smokes 1-2 packs of cigarettes per day. He is on Chantix and is down to a half pack a day.
Flagyl 500 mg every 8 hours; Levaquin 500 mg daily.

Ms. G is a 49-year-old female who presents to the office complaining of ear pain and left-sided headache. The patient states that her pain is better than before but she still wants to get it checked. The patient states that she has been having difficulty hearing and also feeling pressure on the left side of her sinus causing tooth pain. The patient states that she went to her dentist yesterday, and her teeth are fine. The patient denies any fever, cough, sore throat, or any cold-like symptoms. The patient states that she has a sinus problem and chronic left-sided headache. The patient states that she is currently taking Cutivate for her eczema and would like to get a refill for that.
The patient has a good evaluation by the psychiatrist.
This 57-year-old female presents to the office complaining of headaches for the last 6 months.

Her mother died from lung cancer about three to four years ago. Her father has gout and perhaps thrombosis. She has a brother with asthma and uses an inhaler. She has a sister with a tumor removed from her stomach. She is not sure about the family history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, or a stroke.
None.
Noncontributory.

The patient is a 53-year-old male with multiple complaints of hernia, lower extremity pain, and tingling and numbness. He is brought in to emergency room with multiple complaints of nausea, vomiting, and possibly he has had some hematologic bleeding. The patient also has a history of multiple CVA, Peripheral vascular disease, heart failure, and multiple bowel ischemia. His wife is concerned. He is currently on Coumadin for atrial fibrillation, which is subtherapeutic.
Back and shoulder surgery secondary to a skiing accident. Appendectomy as a teenager.

The patient has a history of allergic rhinitis, eczema, sinus problems, and hives. She denies any history of melanoma, skin cancer, or psoriasis. She has a family history of mouth cancer. She does not smoke. She is a nonsmoker. She has been sunburned in the past. She is currently taking benzoyl peroxide and Daypro. She did not bring a blood test today.

Ms. ABC is here for followup on her cervical spinal stenosis. She was seen by me on 06/19/92. On 06/04/92, she had an exacerbated symptom of paresthesia, weakness, and pain in her upper extremities on the right side more than the left. She was referred for cervical spine MRI. Today, she continues to have all of these symptoms and believes that this is coming down from her neck. She has done some physical therapy which has helped with her neck pain, but her right hand is still feeling weak. It is difficult at times to open jars and open doors. Many times, she drops items. The right side is giving her more problems than the left. Sometimes when she is sleeping in the night, she experiences a sharp shooting pain and weakness that goes down her left upper extremity and she feels scared after that. She is seeing Dr. X for this. His methods are working well and are helping her with her neck pain, but not her hand. She has no problems with bowel or bladder problems, back pain, or leg pain. She has no problems with walking or stability.
Focal cervical radiculopathy.
Significant for trauma surgery.

The patient is a 19-year-old male who was in a fight. He punched another man in the face or mouth. He then punched a glass. It broke and spilled all the drink. He thinks he got a cut as it was bleeding badly. He had three cuts in his right hand. When he came to emergency room, the wound was clean and appeared to have been treated. There was a navy corpsman who cleaned the wound with tap water and tried to close it up with gauze and superglue. He said it would stop bleeding, but nothing helped and he was in emergency.
The patient has allergies, eczema, sinus problems, and hives. She is a nonsmoker. She is on benzoyl peroxide and Daypro. She is not a smoker.
Unknown.

The patient is a 58-year-old white female with a history of right knee pain for many years. She has had two arthroscopies. She has tried conservative treatment without long-term relief of symptoms. On the x-rays, she has a collapsing type valgus degenerative osteoarthritis of the lateral compartment with complete collapse and wear of the lateral compartment and degenerative changes noted to the femoral sulcus. The medial compartment is much better compared to the lateral compartment, but she has some significant amount of arthritis. She is able to flex and extend the knee all the way. She has some laxity on both sides of the knee.
